binary.title: Binary Format
binary.whatItIs: Uses only digits 0 and 1, representing how computers store IP addresses at the hardware level
binary.usage: Low-level networking, subnet calculations, understanding binary operations
binary.howToRead: Each octet is 8 bits. Binary 11000000 = 128+64 = 192 decimal

decimal.title: Decimal Format
decimal.whatItIs: The entire IP as a single large number (0-4,294,967,295)
decimal.usage: Database storage, mathematical operations, IP range calculations

hexadecimal.title: Hexadecimal Format
hexadecimal.whatItIs: Uses digits 0-9 and letters A-F, common in programming and low-level operations
hexadecimal.usage: Programming, system logs, network debugging, firmware configuration
hexadecimal.conversion: 192 = C0 hex, 168 = A8 hex. Each hex digit represents 4 binary bits

octal.title: Octal Format
octal.whatItIs: Uses digits 0-7, less common but still found in some configurations
octal.usage: Legacy Unix configurations, file permissions, some network tools
octal.note: Leading zeros indicate octal format. 0300 octal = 192 decimal

specialRanges.title: Special Ranges
specialRanges.classD: Class D (224-239): Multicast addresses for group communication
specialRanges.classE: Class E (240-255): Reserved for experimental use
